awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  EAGER:  Customized cell biosensors for interrogating cancer cell physiology
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the physiological state of normal and cancerous tumor cells has limited our understanding of how cells grow and respond to their environment.  In this collaborative project the PIs will construct synthetic living biosensors that can be mixed with other cells to provide readily detectable and measurable information on the cells physiological state, including the response of tumor cells to therapeutic agents.  This will improve our ability to model normal and cancer cell biology, contributing to our understanding of how potential therapeutic agents affect cells.  This approach will permit detecting multiple physiological states simultaneously, in a high-throughput manner.  In terms of broader impacts this project will enhance ongoing outreach activities to engage undergraduate students, K-12 students, and the public in STEM through several ongoing programs at each institution as well as by new activities to enhance interactions between institutions.

This project will develop synthetic biology tools and experimental approaches that will enable the development of more sophisticated models of normal and cancer cell physiological properties, including information about the immediate environment and response to therapeutic agents.  The first step will be to develop genetically encoded live cell sensors that will report information about multiple cell physiological states, including treatment biomarkers.  The second step will be to develop real-time reporting by the sensors via loading of barcoded synthetic RNA molecules distinct for each biomarker to be detected by next-generation sequencing.  The goal of this EAGER is to develop and validate each of the key technological foundations required to be successful. In terms of broader impacts, this project will contribute to the training of the next generation work-force in synthetic, cellular, and cancer biology. This project will also include cross-institutional virtual meetings to enhance student networking by the iGEM  teams at each institution.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
This project pioneered the development and use of novel technologies for programming living cells to create biotechnologies that benefit human health. The team developed a series of novel genetic sensors and circuits that can be encoded in DNA and thus delivered into cells much like a virus infects a cell, but in this case the programming causes the cells to carry out a novel and defined function—sensing and responding to low concentrations of oxygen (a common feature of tumors and disease sites) by expressing an engineered output gene. Such a reprogrammed cell can function as a sentinel, exploring the body and reporting out upon what it observes at the very local level. Such an approach is designed to overcome challenges associated with research into complex environments within the body, and it can one day be adapted to create cell therapies. This project manifests a core principle of synthetic biology – by building new systems, we can better understand natural systems. In this case, computational modeling was employed to study the synthetic biosensors; this approach created new knowledge as to how natural oxygen-sensing systems work. Modeling-guided insights also provide guidance as to how such genetic circuits may be employed for a variety of applications. Ultimately, the technologies created may benefit both fundamental researchers and the biotechnology industry, by creating new “parts” and knowledge, and together these will ultimately lead to new medicines that improve human health.

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2023
Modified by: Joshua N Leonard
